title: IBAN-based transfer detection for analysis commands
description:
Currently, transfers are detected by checking if a transaction's category falls under the Umbuchungen category tree. This works because MoneyMoney auto-categorizes same-group (same legal entity) transfers as 'Echte Umbuchung' and cross-group transfers get proper income/expense categories (e.g. Gehalt).

However, a structural IBAN-based approach would be more robust: detect transfers by checking if the counterparty's IBAN matches one of the user's own accounts.

Key concept: group = legal entity.
- Same-group transfer (e.g. Privat→Privat): internal shuffle, exclude
- Cross-group transfer (e.g. cognovis→Privat salary): real cashflow, keep

Implementation:
1. Add counterparty_iban field to Transaction model (from plist accountNumber field)
2. Build own-IBAN set from accounts
3. Match counterparty IBAN against own accounts
4. Same-group → exclude, cross-group → keep
5. Keep category-based detection as fallback (credit card settlements lack counterparty IBAN)

This also serves as validation for correct Umbuchungen categorization and catches uncategorized transfers.
close_reason: Implemented IBAN-based transfer detection. counterparty_iban field added to Transaction, filter_transfers rewritten with IBAN+group logic, all 5 analyze commands wired up. 7 new tests, live tested.

title: Expose additional MoneyMoney AppleScript functionality
description:
## Overview
MoneyMoney provides extensive AppleScript automation beyond basic data retrieval. This ticket covers exposing all additional capabilities through the CLI.

## Reference
Official documentation: https://moneymoney.app/applescript/

## Additional Commands to Implement

### Portfolio Management
#### `mm portfolio`
Export securities holdings.
- AppleScript: `export portfolio from account ... as "plist"`
- Options:
  - `--account` / `-a`: Specific account (optional, all if omitted)
- Output: Security name, ISIN, quantity, value, performance

### Bank Transfers
#### `mm transfer`
Create a bank transfer.
- AppleScript: `create bank transfer from account ... to ... iban ... amount ... purpose ...`
- Arguments:
  - `--from-account`: Source account
  - `--to`: Recipient name
  - `--iban`: Recipient IBAN
  - `--amount`: Transfer amount
  - `--purpose`: Transfer purpose/reference
- Options:
  - `--outbox`: Save to outbox without opening UI
  - `--dry-run`: Show transfer details without creating

#### `mm batch-transfer`
Import SEPA-XML batch transfer.
- AppleScript: `create batch transfer from POSIX file ...`
- Arguments:
  - `file`: Path to SEPA-XML file
- Options:
  - `--validate`: Validate XML without importing

### Direct Debits
#### `mm direct-debit`
Create a direct debit.
- AppleScript: `create direct debit from account ... for ... iban ... amount ... purpose ... mandate reference ... mandate date ... scheduled date ...`
- Arguments:
  - `--from-account`: Creditor account
  - `--for`: Debtor name
  - `--iban`: Debtor IBAN
  - `--amount`: Debit amount
  - `--purpose`: Purpose text
  - `--mandate-ref`: SEPA mandate reference
  - `--mandate-date`: Mandate signature date (YYYY-MM-DD)
  - `--scheduled-date`: Execution date (YYYY-MM-DD)
- Options:
  - `--outbox`: Save to outbox without opening UI

#### `mm batch-direct-debit`
Import SEPA-XML batch direct debit.
- AppleScript: `create batch direct debit from POSIX file ...`
- Arguments:
  - `file`: Path to SEPA-XML file

### Offline Account Management
#### `mm add-transaction`
Add transaction to offline account.
- AppleScript: `add transaction to account ... on date ... to ... amount ... purpose ... category ...`
- Arguments:
  - `--account`: Target offline account name
  - `--date`: Transaction date (YYYY-MM-DD)
  - `--to`: Payee/recipient name
  - `--amount`: Transaction amount (negative for expenses)
  - `--purpose`: Description/purpose
  - `--category`: Category name (optional)

### Transaction Management
#### `mm set-checkmark`
Set/unset transaction checkmark.
- AppleScript: `set transaction id [ID] checkmark to "on"/"off"`
- Arguments:
  - `transaction_id`: Transaction ID
  - `state`: on/off

#### `mm set-comment`
Add/update transaction note.
- AppleScript: `set transaction id [ID] comment to ...`
- Arguments:
  - `transaction_id`: Transaction ID
  - `comment`: Note text

### Export Enhancements
#### `mm export`
Unified export command with format options.
- Subcommands:
  - `mm export transactions --format csv/plist/json`
  - `mm export accounts --format plist/json`
  - `mm export categories --format plist/json`
  - `mm export portfolio --format plist/json`

## Implementation Notes

### Safety Considerations
- Transfer and direct debit commands should require `--confirm` flag or interactive confirmation
- Add `--dry-run` to all write operations
- Validate IBAN format before sending to AppleScript
- Validate dates and amounts

### Command Groups
Organize commands into logical groups:
- `mm accounts` - Account operations
- `mm transactions` - Transaction queries
- `mm categories` - Category management
- `mm transfers` - Transfer operations (transfer, batch-transfer)
- `mm debits` - Direct debit operations (direct-debit, batch-direct-debit)
- `mm portfolio` - Securities/portfolio

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All additional AppleScript commands exposed via CLI
- [ ] Safety confirmations for write operations
- [ ] IBAN validation
- [ ] Date format validation
- [ ] SEPA-XML validation for batch imports
- [ ] Comprehensive --help for all commands
- [ ] Integration tests with MoneyMoney (manual verification)
close_reason: Split into specific beads: mm-cli-0kt (portfolio), mm-cli-t41 (checkmark/comment), mm-cli-qpf (transfer). Direct debit, batch operations, and offline accounts dropped as not needed.

title: Fix category hierarchy - categories export is flat, losing parent-child structure
description:
## Problem
The mm categories command returns all 106 categories as flat/root-level items with no parent information. MoneyMoney's export categories AppleScript returns a flat plist. However, transaction data contains full category paths with backslash separators (e.g. Malte\Ausgaben\Leben\Ernährung), proving the hierarchy exists.

## Root Cause  
MoneyMoney's export categories plist has no children arrays. The _parse_category_tree() in applescript.py:228 handles children but there are none.

## Solution
Reconstruct hierarchy from transaction category paths. Export transactions, collect unique category paths, build tree from backslash-separated paths. Map category UUIDs via categoryUuid field.

## Impact
- 106 categories shown flat with no hierarchy
- Duplicate names (3x Sonstiges, 3x Nebenkosten, 2x Ausgaben) are indistinguishable
- Cannot suggest proper categories for uncategorized transactions

title: Implement core CLI commands for MoneyMoney interaction
description:
## Overview
Implement the core CLI commands to interact with MoneyMoney macOS app via AppleScript. This is the foundation for all MoneyMoney data access.

## Commands to Implement

### 1. `mm accounts`
List all accounts from MoneyMoney database.
- AppleScript: `export accounts`
- Returns: Account ID, name, balance, type, bank name
- Output formats: table (default), json

### 2. `mm transactions`
List transactions with filtering options.
- AppleScript: `export transactions from account ... from date ... to date ... as "plist"`
- Options:
  - `--account` / `-a`: Filter by account ID or name
  - `--from` / `-f`: Start date (YYYY-MM-DD)
  - `--to` / `-t`: End date (YYYY-MM-DD)  
  - `--category` / `-c`: Filter by category
  - `--uncategorized`: Show only uncategorized transactions
- Output formats: table (default), json, csv

### 3. `mm categories`
List all categories from MoneyMoney.
- AppleScript: `export categories`
- Returns: Category UUID, name, parent category, type (income/expense)
- Output formats: table (default), json

### 4. `mm category-usage`
Show categories sorted by transaction count.
- Requires: transactions export + category mapping
- Output: Category name, transaction count, total amount
- Options:
  - `--from` / `-f`: Start date
  - `--to` / `-t`: End date
  - `--limit` / `-n`: Top N categories

### 5. `mm set-category`
Update the category of a transaction.
- AppleScript: `set transaction id [ID] category to [UUID]`
- Arguments:
  - `transaction_id`: Transaction ID (from plist export)
  - `category`: Category name or UUID
- Options:
  - `--dry-run`: Show what would be changed without applying

## Technical Implementation

### AppleScript Module (`mm_cli/applescript.py`)
- `run_applescript(script: str) -> str`: Execute AppleScript via osascript
- `export_accounts() -> list[dict]`: Get all accounts
- `export_transactions(...) -> list[dict]`: Get transactions with filters
- `export_categories() -> list[dict]`: Get all categories
- `set_transaction_category(tx_id: str, category_id: str) -> bool`: Update category

### Models (`mm_cli/models.py`)
- `Account`: dataclass for account data
- `Transaction`: dataclass for transaction data
- `Category`: dataclass for category data

### Output Formatting (`mm_cli/output.py`)
- Rich tables for terminal output
- JSON serialization
- CSV export

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All 5 commands implemented and working
- [ ] Proper error handling for AppleScript failures
- [ ] Rich formatted tables for human-readable output
- [ ] JSON output option for machine processing
- [ ] Unit tests with mocked AppleScript responses
- [ ] `--help` documentation for all commands
close_reason: All 5 CLI commands implemented with full test coverage

title: Add suggest-rules command for MoneyMoney auto-categorization analysis
description:
## Context
MoneyMoney has NO AppleScript API for reading or managing rules as separate entities (confirmed via .sdef scripting dictionary). HOWEVER, the export categories plist DOES include a 'rules' field on each category containing the MoneyMoney rule text. This is now parsed and available in mm-cli via the Category.rules field.

## What's Already Available (after mm-cli-dyg fix)
- Category.rules: The MoneyMoney rule text for each category
- Category.path: Full hierarchical path (e.g. Malte\Ausgaben\Leben\Ernährung)
- Category.indentation: Nesting level
- Category.group: Whether it's a group/folder
- mm categories --format json: Full data including rules

## Feature: mm suggest-rules
Analyze transaction data to suggest NEW MoneyMoney rules:
1. Find uncategorized transactions, match against patterns from categorized ones
2. Suggest rules based on recurring payee patterns
3. Compare against existing rules to avoid duplicates
4. Detect PayPal + direct merchant duplicates (same amount, same date)

## Output Example
Pattern                        | Category      | Matches | Existing Rule?
Name contains Apple.com.Bill   | Subscriptions | 4       | Partial (Apple.com/Bill in Sonstige Unterhaltung)
Name contains Versicherung     | Versicherung  | 4       | No

## Implementation
- Use export_transactions() for transaction data
- Use export_categories() for existing rules
- Build payee->category mapping from categorized transactions
- Compare suggested rules against existing Category.rules
- Apply fuzzy matching (normalize PayPal names, strip location suffixes)
- Use historical data for better matching
